text: @MightyKreskin @Keirwales The neurodiversity movement is about trying to get society to change (to be more accepting and accommodating of autism, ADHD) rather than trying to change the autistic person to be less autistic. This doesn't mean providing no support to the autistic person.

text: @Kattvnnen1 @AviusL @commaficionado "Autist" (noun) is what most autistics who are involved in the neurodiversity movement in Sweden call ourselves. "Autistisk" (adjective) is less common here. "Person med autism" is still the most common one among people who are less educated by autistics.

text:

Who on earth is INDIVIDUALLY neurodiverse? Sure, my gut microbiome is diverse, but I am not diverse. Together, we humans are diverse.

Source: https://t.co/YoPd3P3v0H https://t.co/UhviQK4RDR

text: Being ‚Äòneurodiverse‚Äô is not a thing. Neurodiversity refers to a group of people with different brain types, including neurotypical‚Äôs and neurodivergent‚Äôs. Nicotine is not "addictive."  It is dependence-forming for some, but not everyone.  It is particularly dependence-forming for adults living with #neurodiversity issues because it helps them.  Reduces symptoms.

text: I think neuroatypical more clearly separates itself from the concept of neurodiversity, and recognizes that there is no one approach that works for every one of the disorders that falls under its umbrella. Overall, I find neurodivergent to be useless at best.

text: Neurodivergence as an idea, which was designed to cover anyone with any mental health disorder or neurological condition, is in direct opposition to the anti-cure position of neurodiversity. It was explicitly coined to widen neurodiverse and redefine neurotypical.
tokenized_text: neurodivergence as an idea , which was designed to cover anyone with any mental health disorder or neurological condition , is in direct opposition to the anti - cure position of neurodiversity . it was explicitly coined to widen neurodiverse and redefine neurotypical .

text: The emphasis is on 'without external cause' because some people argue that the brain structure thing makes disorders like C/PTSD and DID inherently neurodiverse. But the whole point of neurodiversity is to recognize normal variations and advocate against eugenics.

But I never come to any useful conclusions about it.

text: @mykola My purely personal view is that neurodiversity is the spectrum, and we show traits of the various ND conditions in a variety of ways. Our brains are different from NT, but it may show as dyslexia or AuDHD, or dyspraxic autism or any other combination.
tokenized_text: <user> my purely personal view is that neurodiversity is the spectrum , and we show traits of the various nd conditions in a variety of ways . our brains are different from nt , but it may show as dyslexia or audhd , or dyspraxic autism or any other combination .

I don't think time is a real concept. That's mostly cos I can't seem to keep track of it. So I have this habit of constantly wanting to know what time it is. I feel like this is also how I store my memories- obsessively recording it to the last minute.

@npaa_uk What Jon said. Humanity is neurodiverse. The Neurodiversity Paradigm is about appreciating that diversity for the benefit of all.
And it is broad by design - it's autism, dyspraxia, it's hearing voices and smelling colours, it's personality, it's community, it's humanity.

text: @LeanneRussell2 Many researchers are trying to find ways of "curing" or preemptively eliminating autism. It can seem a caring approach, but there are unique intelligences that are part of neurodiversity that we would lose. I advocate for embracing ND while finding help for the hard bits.
tokenized_text: <user> many researchers are trying to find ways of " curing " or preemptively eliminating autism . it can seem a caring approach , but there are unique intelligences that are part of neurodiversity that we would lose . i advocate for embracing nd while finding help for the hard bits .

text: @thetimverse @AutismTalkAspie I do as well. I am also working to bring awareness to the metal and physical challenges that come with neurodiversity. I feel a balanced approach is very important so that none of us are undervalued for our strengths nor unseen and unaccommodated for what challenges us.
